definitions.definition: any of the hard parts that form the skeleton of the body of a human or an animal

examples.text: He survived the accident with no **broken bones**.
This fish has a lot of bones in it.
She went for a **bone density** scan.
The dog was gnawing at a bone.
She had a beautiful face with very good bone structure.
She was diagnosed as having brittle bones.
The shock jarred every bone in his body.
the delicate bones in your ear

definitions.definition: the hard substance that bones are made of

examples.text: knives with bone handles

definitions.definition: having bones of the type mentioned

examples.text: fine-boned

definitions.definition: a very thin person or animal

examples.text: The cat hadn’t been fed for weeks and was just a bag of bones.
the bare bones of the story

definitions.definition: a subject that causes people to disagree

examples.text: Where to go on holiday is always a bone of contention in our family.

definitions.definition: so honest or clearly expressed that it is likely to cause offence to some people

examples.text: His comments were getting a bit close to the bone so I changed the subject.
Some of the sex scenes in the play were judged by critics to be too close to the bone.

definitions.definition: to reduce something, such as costs, as much as you possibly can

examples.text: Their annual budget has already been pared to the bone.

definitions.definition: to be certain about something even though you do not have any direct proof and cannot explain why you are certain

examples.text: I know I'm going to fail this exam—I can feel it in my bones.

definitions.definition: to be angry with somebody about something and want to discuss it with them
very determined and refusing to give up

examples.text: When she sensed a good story she was like a dog with a bone.

definitions.definition: to be honest and open about something; to not hesitate to do something

examples.text: She made no bones about telling him exactly what she thought of him.

definitions.definition: to have none of the quality mentioned

examples.text: She was honest and hard-working, and didn't have an unkind bone in her body.

definitions.definition: to develop a basic idea, etc. by giving more details to make it more complete

examples.text: The strength of the book is that it puts flesh on the bare bones of this argument.

definitions.definition: extremely thin in a way that is not attractive or healthy

examples.text: The dog lost more and more weight, and was soon little more than skin and bone.
He's all skin and bone after his illness.

definitions.definition: to give somebody a small part of what they want as a way of showing that you want to help them, without offering them the main thing they want

examples.text: She feels this new energy bill is just throwing a bone to the environmentalists.
His threats chilled her to the bone.

wordOrigin: Old English bān, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch been and German Bein.
